{{good article}} {{Taxobox | image = Cortinarius iodes 101027.jpg | image_width = 234px | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Cortinariaceae]] | genus = ''[[Cortinarius]]'' | species = '''''C. iodes''''' | binomial = ''Cortinarius iodes'' | binomial_authority = [[Berk.]] & [[M.A.Curtis]] (1853) }}
'''''Cortinarius iodes''''', commonly known as the '''spotted cort''' or the '''viscid violet cort''', is a species of [[agaric]] fungus in the family [[Cortinariaceae]]. The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] have small, slimy, purple [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] up to {{convert|6|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter that develop yellowish spots and streaks in maturity. The [[lamella (mycology)|gill]] color changes from violet to rusty or grayish brown as the mushroom matures. The species range includes the eastern North America, Central America, northern South America, and northern Asia, where it grows on the ground in a [[mycorrhiza]]l association with [[deciduous]] trees. Although [[edible mushroom|edible]], the mushroom is not recommended for consumption. ''[[Cortinarius iodeoides]]'', one of several potential lookalike species, can be distinguished from ''C. iodes'' by its bitter-tasting [[cap cuticle]].
== Taxonomy == The species was first [[species description|described]] scientifically by [[Miles Joseph Berkeley]] and [[Moses Ashley Curtis]] in 1853. The [[type (biology)|type]] collection was made by American botanist [[Henry William Ravenel]] in [[South Carolina]].<ref name="Berkeley 1853"/> [[Joseph Ammirati]] and [[Howard Bigelow]] considered ''Cortinarius heliotropicus'', described by [[Charles Horton Peck]] 1914, to be the same species as ''C. iodes'' after examining the [[holotype]] specimens of both.<ref name="Ammirati 1984"/> According to the nomenclatural databases [[MycoBank]] and [[Index Fungorum]], however, ''Cortinarius iodes'' does not have any [[synonym (biology)|synonyms]].<ref name="urlMycoBank: Cortinarius iodes"/><ref name="urlFungorum: Cortinarius iodes"/> If they are indeed the same species, the name ''C. iodes'' has [[correct name (botany)|priority]].<ref name="Ammirati 1984"/> ''C. iodes'' is [[classification (biology)|classified]] in the [[subgenus]] ''Myxacium'', along with other ''Cortinarius'' species that have a slimy cap and stem.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/>
The [[botanical name|specific epithet]] ''iodes'' means "violet-like". It is [[common name|commonly]] known as the "spotted cort" or the "viscid violet cort".<ref name="Roody 2003"/>
== Description == [[File:Cortinarius iodes 17924.jpg|thumb|left|Mature caps develop characteristic yellowish spots. A wispy, rusty brown annular zone is visible on the upper stem.]] The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is initially bell-shaped before becoming broadly convex and then flat in maturity (sometimes retaining a broad [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]]), and attains a diameter of {{convert|2|–|6|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}. The cap surface is slimy (in wet weather) and smooth, and has a [[lilac (color)|lilac]] or purplish color.<ref name="Bessette 1997"/> The flesh is white, firm, and thin.<ref name="Bessette 1987"/> The color fades in maturity, and the cap develops irregular yellowish spots, or becomes yellowish in the center. [[Lamella (mycology)|Gills]] are attached to the stem and packed together closely. They are lilac to violet when young, but become rusty brown to grayish cinnamon when the spores mature. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] measures {{convert|4|–|7|cm|in|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|0.5|–|1.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, and is nearly equal in width throughout other than a somewhat bulbous base. It is solid (i.e., not hollow), slimy, smooth, and has violet or purplish colors that are usually lighter than the cap; sometimes, the stem base is more or less white. The cobweb-like, pale violet [[partial veil]] leaves a zone of thin, purple or rusty fibers on the upper stem. The mushroom has no distinctive taste or odor.<ref name="Bessette 1997"/> Although [[edible mushroom|edible]], it is not recommended for consumption.<ref name="Phillips 2005"/><ref name="Kibby 1994"/>
''Cortinarius iodes'' produces a rusty-brown [[spore print]]. [[Spore]]s are elliptical, with a finely roughened surface, measuring 8–10 by 5–6.5 [[micrometre|μm]].<ref name="Bessette 1997"/> The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are four-spored, club-shaped, and measure 28–39.5 by 9.3–14 μm. Both cheliocystidia and pleurocystidia are absent from the [[hymenium]]; the gill edge is populated by basidia and their undeveloped equivalents, basidioles. The cap cuticle comprises a distinctive layer of 3–8 μm-wide [[hypha]]e that form a layer usually 110–125 μm thick; this layer is less distinct or thinner in old or poorly preserved specimens. [[Clamp connection]]s are present in hyphae throughout the fruit body.<ref name="Ammirati 1984"/>
=== Similar species === {{multiple image | footer = | align = right | image1 = Cortinarius violaceus 02.jpg | width1 = {{#expr: (160 * 1317 / 1600) round 0}} | caption1 = ''Cortinarius violaceus'' | image2 = Inocybe lilacina 265529.jpg | width2 = {{#expr: (160 * 2304 / 3456) round 0}} | caption2 = ''Inocybe lilacina'' }} ''Cortinarius iodes'' is a fairly distinctive species and its combination of characteristics make it readily identifiable. Several other ''Cortinarius'' species have evolved a slimy coating that probably help protects the fruit bodies from predation by insects and other invertebrates. Other field techniques can be used to help identify dry fruit bodies that have lost their slime coat: by checking for leaf and twig debris adhering to the surface, or, by kissing the cap and stem to exploit the lips' enhanced sensitivity to stickiness.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> ''[[Cortinarius iodeoides|C. iodeoides]]'' is virtually identical in appearance to ''C. iodes'', but can be distinguished from the latter by its bitter-tasting cap cuticle<ref name="Roody 2003"/> and smaller, narrower spores measuring 7.7–9.3 by 4.6–5.4 μm.<ref name="Ammirati 1984"/> The "violet cort" (''[[Cortinarius violaceus]]'') has a dry, scaly, dark purple cap and stem. The "pungent cort" (''[[Cortinarius traganus]]'') has a dry, light purple cap and stem and a bad odor.<ref name="Bessette 1987"/> Two other widespread ''Cortinarius'' species with violet coloring and a slimy cap, ''[[Cortinarius salor|C. salor]]'' and ''[[Cortinarius croceocaeruleus|C. croceocaeruleus]]'', can be distinguished from ''C. iodes'' by the absence of yellowish spotting.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> A North American species ''[[Cortinarius oregonensis|C. oregonensis]]'' has a paler lilac cap with a central region that is yellowish or brownish, and smaller spores that measure 7–8 by 4–5 μm.<ref name="Smith 1939"/> A non-''Cortinarius'' lookalike, ''[[Inocybe lilacina]]'', has a dry, silky cap that features a prominent umbo.<ref name="Roody 2003"/>
== Habitat and distribution == ''Cortinarius iodes'' forms [[mycorrhiza]]l associations with [[deciduous]] trees, particularly [[oak]]s.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> The fruit bodies of ''Cortinarius iodes'' sometimes grow singly, but more often scattered or in groups under hardwood trees, in [[humus]] and [[litterfall]]. Typical habitats include [[bog]] edges, swampy areas, and [[hummock]]s. Fruiting usually occurs from July to November.<ref name="Ammirati 1984"/> In North America, it is common in eastern regions, and rare in the [[Pacific Northwest]].<ref name="Phillips 2005"/> Its distribution extends from eastern Canada south into Central America and northern regions of South America. It also occurs in northern Asia.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/>
